options.content:
# IPFS Monitoring Metrics

Various metrics extracted from IPFS nodes with unlimited connection capacity and the messages they receive.

### Research Work

As a complement to this interactive dashboard, please have a look at our paper titled [Monitoring Data Requests in Decentralized Data Storage Systems: A Case Study of IPFS](https://arxiv.org/abs/2104.09202), which will be publish at this year's [ICDCS](https://icdcs2022.icdcs.org/) conference.
Feel free to contact me (see below) with any questions or comments!

### Metrics

We use and display:
- Metrics built into IPFS
- Real-time analyses of incoming Bitswap traffic, performed by our [real-time analysis client](https://github.com/trudi-group/ipfs-tools/tree/master/bitswap-monitoring-client)
- Metrics about/extracted from the IPFS node added by our [plugin](https://github.com/trudi-group/ipfs-metric-exporter), and about the plugin state itself

**Most visualizations have a description.**
You can view that with the tiny `i` in the top-left corner of the visualization.

#### Visualization Options

You can find a selector for the **visualized time range for all visualizations** in the top right-hand corner of the page.
Next to that you can switch to **kiosk mode** to remove some more visual clutter, but this is of course optional.
In addition to that, each plot can be
- viewed in full-screen mode by pressing `V` on its title-bar (or selecting "View" from its menu)
- selected to show only specific time-series by clicking them in the legend. Multiple series can be selected by holding `Shift` while clicking
- used to select a time range to display by selecting it with the mouse in the visualization

#### Sections

This dashboard consists of multiple collapsible sections.
Each section usually has some information about the data displayed and methodology used to obtain it.
You can also collapse this message using the "Intro" section above it.
Collapsing sections helps performance, both on your and our end.

### Setup

We're using [this docker compose](https://github.com/trudi-group/ipfs-metric-exporter/tree/master/docker-compose) setup.
We are continuously updating our infrastructure to keep up-to-date with latest releases of kubo and new features.

#### Datasets

The data visualized here is produced and consumed in real-time, and stored in prometheus.
We also have large traces of Bitswap traffic.
If you're interested in any of the data, or have questions about it, please don't hesitate to contact me (see below).
See also our [privacy policy](https://monitoring.ipfs.trudi.group/privacy_policy.html) about data retention and usage policies.

### Contact/See also

By Leo @ [Team TruDi](https://trudi.group), Berlin/Darmstadt.
Contact me via [email](mailto:leonhard.balduf@tu-darmstadt.de).
See also:
- The [plugin](https://github.com/trudi-group/ipfs-metric-exporter) we develop to do this
- The [analysis client](https://github.com/trudi-group/ipfs-tools/tree/master/bitswap-monitoring-client) used to ingest Bitswap traffic
- The [size estimator](https://github.com/trudi-group/ipfs-tools/tree/master/monitoring-size-estimator) we use to estimate network size

### Network Size Estimates

Estimates of the total network size and the size of peer populations supporting given protocols.
This is calculated using the [monitoring size estimator](https://github.com/trudi-group/ipfs-tools/tree/master/monitoring-size-estimator) tool.

#### Estimated Sizes

This estimates the size of the entire IPFS network, including DHT servers and clients.

For specific protocols, the two samples obtained by the monitor are filtered for peers indicating support for the given protocol.
These filtered samples are then used to estimate the total size of the subset of peers of the IPFS network supporting the given protocol.

Furthermore, we estimate the size of the network populace running a given agent version using the same approach.
This should, in theory, categorize the network into disjoint sets, which in sum should add up to the entire network size.
As can be seen, this does not hold.
We suspect that these samples are not uniform for every agent version, i.e., some agents have a bias in their connection preference.

#### Estimators

We implement two estimators:
- A hypergeometric estimator which is fast and simple, but only works for pairs of monitors.
  For this estimator, we evaluate all pairs of monitors.
- An estimator based on the coupon collector's problem.
  This needs to be solved numerically and is somewhat slow, doesn't always return a result, but can operate on arbitrarily large sets of monitors.
  As a simplification, we use the average number of peers over all monitors as the number of connections per monitor.

For details, please read our [paper](https://arxiv.org/abs/2104.09202).

#### Caveats

Both estimators assume uniform sampling.
We have confirmed that this holds for large monitoring nodes, which makes estimates of the total network size probably somewhat accurate.
This also means that for protocols without special peer selection, accurate estimates are possible.

However, this **does not work for subsets of peers with non-uniform connectivity**.
In particular, this **does not work for DHT size estimations**, because Kademlia connection are not a uniform sample of the total peer population.

It also looks like it **does not work for all agent versions**.

panels.description: Averages over all monitor pairs of the hypergeometric estimator and the coupon collector estimator.
panels.title: Average Network Size Estimate
Latest Peer Population Estimates by Agent Version, Top 10, Average over Estimators
Size Estimates for Agent Versions, Hypergeometric Estimator
Size Estimates for Agent Versions, Coupon Collector Estimator
Size Estimates per Protocol, Hypergeometric Estimator
Size Estimates per Protocol, Coupon Collector Estimator
Agent Version Population Sizes, Average over Estimators

targets.legendFormat: Coupon Collector Estimator, Sum over all Agent Versions
Hypergeometric Estimator, Sum over all Agent Versions, {{monitor_pair}}

panels.title: Size Estimates for the Entire Network by Estimator

options.content:
### Bitswap Realtime Analysis

Our [plugin](https://github.com/trudi-group/ipfs-metric-exporter) exports all incoming Bitswap traffic and connection events via a TCP server.
We have a [client](https://github.com/trudi-group/ipfs-tools/tree/master/bitswap-monitoring-client), which connects to this, performs analyses, and exports results via Prometheus.

#### Bitswap in a Nutshell

Bitswap sends messages between peers.
For recent versions of the protocol, each message may contain any combination of
- A wantlist, which encapsulates requests. This can be either `full`, replacing the previous state at the remote peer, or incremental.
- A list of blocks, addressed by their CID.
- A list of block presence responses.

A wantlist in turn contains a list of entries:
- Request entries `WANT_HAVE` and `WANT_BLOCK`, in addition to an optional `send_dont_have` flag
- `CANCEL` entries, which cancel an outstanding request.

Block presence responses are either `HAVE` or `DONT_HAVE`.
These are returned for `WANT_HAVE` requests.
The `DONT_HAVE` is optional, and returned if `send_dont_have` is requested.
Most peers support this.

#### Requests and Responses

In general, our monitoring nodes sit passively and record all incoming traffic.
Usually, these incoming messages are requests only.  
However, we recently added functionality to also query all of our peers via Bitswap, in a controlled manner.
This then leads to our monitors also received responses, in the form of blocks and block presences.
This generally happens in short, fast bursts, when we sample the network for a set of CIDs.

#### Deduplication

Real-time analyses performed use the raw, non-deduplicated Bitswap traffic recorded by the monitors.
Bitswap sends a lot of duplicate entries, most of which are useless, since the wantlist state is persisted on remote peers for as long as the connection is alive.
This is a known issue, and in the future we will also support analyzing deduplicated traffic.

panels.description:
Rate of Bitswap messages received per second.
This counts Bitswap _messages_, which in turn may include requests, responses, blocks, and block presences.
Calculated over 30 minutes.
panels.title: Bitswap Messages Received/s

panels.description:
Rate of wantlists received per second, by whether they were full or incremental.
This counts messages for which the wantlist is not empty.
Calculated over a 30 minute window.
panels.title: Wantlists Received/s

panels.description:
Rate of wantlist entries received per second.
In sum over all entry types, request types only, and CANCEL types only.
Calculated over a 30 minute window.
panels.title: Wantlist Entries/s: Total, Requests Only, CANCEL Only

panels.description:
Rate of wantlist entries received per second, by entry type and send_dont_have flag.
This is calculated over a 30 minute window.
panels.title: Wantlist Entries Received/s
Bitswap Messages Received/s by Public Gateway Status
Wantlist Entries Received/s by Public Gateway Status

panels.description:
The rate of block presence entries received per second.
Calculated over a 30 minute window.
panels.title: Block Presences Received/s

panels.description:
The rate of blocks received per second.
Calculate over a 30 minute window.
panels.title: Blocks Received/s

options.content:
### Bitswap Message and Connection Event Geolocation

Addresses are located using the [MaxMind GeoLite2](https://dev.maxmind.com/geoip/geolite2-free-geolocation-data) database.

#### Countries

Countries are named using the [celes](https://crates.io/crates/celes) crate, which translates ISO 3166-1 2-letter country codes to their full name.

#### Counting

"Bitswap Messages" counts **all** incoming messages.
"Bitswap Requests" counts all **wantlist entries** which are not `CANCEL`s.
See the description of the Bitswap section for more information on this.

#### Deduplication

The notice from the other Bitswap realtime analysis section applies.

#### Aggregation

Note that, for the aggregated values over longer durations, the results may be inaccurate if we don't have enough data for the window.
These metrics are also especially susceptible to downtime.

#### Address Selection

For Bitswap messages, we ask the IPFS node for connections to that peer as soon as we receive a message.
We export this information together with the message via our plugin.
We then select the first non-relayed address out of those.
If no non-relayed connections to the peer exist, we mark its origin as `"Unknown"`.
Due to the inherent racy-ness of Bitswap wiretapping and asking the peer store for connections to the peer, some messages have no origin, or out-of-date connection info.
We believe this does not happen often.

For connection events, we get the address as part of the event and use it.

Wantlist entries receive the origin country of the parent message.

#### Error Handling

The `"Unknown"` group contains:
- Relayed connections
- Address for which no entry is in the database
- Addresses for which the entry does not list a `country`

The `"Error"` group contains:
- Addresses for which the lookup failed

panels.title: Bitswap Messages Received/s, by Origin Country

panels.description:
Rate of non-CANCEL wantlist entries received per second.
Calculated over a 30 minute window.
panels.title: Bitswap Requests Received/s by Origin Country

panels.description:
Rate of non-CANCEL wantlist entries received per second.
Calculated over a one-day window.
panels.title: Top 10 Requesting Countries, Last 24h

panels.description:
Rate of non-CANCEL wantlist entries received per second.
Calculated over a seven-day window.
panels.title: Top 10 Requesting Countries, Last 7d

panels.description:
Rate of non-CANCEL wantlist entries received per second.
Calculated over a thirty-day window.
panels.title: Top 10 Requesting Countries, Last 30d

options.content:
### IPFS Node Connectivity and Network-level Metrics

IPFS itself exports various metrics about its connectivity.
We augment those with our plugin, adding information about open streams, supported protocols among connected peers, and others.

#### Counting

Some care must be taken to counting peers:  
IPFS can hold multiple connections to the same peer.
IPFS itself [used to](https://github.com/ipfs/go-ipfs/issues/8573) count and report connections, but this has changed in recent versions.

We try to make it obvious in all our visualizations, which way we're counting.
Please also refer to the respective descriptions.

#### Agent Versions

As agent versions are somewhat user-chosen, we limit the number of agent versions we report on using the plugin, in order not to generate a large amount of timeseries in prometheus.

#### Plugin-internal Metrics

Recent versions of our [plugin](https://github.com/trudi-group/ipfs-metric-exporter) contain functionality to broadcast Bitswap requests to all connected peers in a controlled manner.
This is used to discover the locations of, and track CIDs over time.

In order for this to function, the plugin tries to maintain a Bitswap sender to every connected peer.
This is achieved through listening to connection events generated by IPFS.
These events are a bit racy and unreliable, and generally lag behind the true state of affairs a bit.
As such, we export metrics about the "view" of peers and connections from the point of view of the plugin, as well as how many Bitswap senders are currently available.

panels.description:
The number of open connections, in sum over all transports.
This counts multiple connections to the same peer multiple times, for older versions of IPFS.
panels.title: Number of Peers/Connections

panels.description:
The number of open connections, by transport.
This counts multiple connections to the same peer multiple times, for older versions of IPFS.
panels.title: Number of Peers/Connections by Transport

panels.description:
The number of DHT servers vs. non-DHT servers, i.e. clients, among the peers we are connected to.
This is calculated based on whether the peer reports that they speak the /ipfs/kad/1.0.0 protocol.
This counts by peer ID.
panels.title: Number of DHT Servers/Clients among Connected Peers

panels.description:
Sum of supported protocols over all currently connected peers, as reported by the IPFS node.
This counts by peer ID.
panels.title: Supported Protocols of Connected Peers

panels.description:
The plugin attempts to hold a Bitswap sender to every peer the node is connected to.
In order to do this, it uses connection notification mechanisms of the IPFS node, which are a bit imprecise and usually lag behind the true connectivity of the node.
This tracks the number of peers, connections, and available Bitswap senders, for the plugin.
panels.title: Plugin: Available Bitswap Senders and Tracked Peers/Connections

panels.description: Number of currently connected peers, distinguished by their agent_version. This counts by peer ID.
panels.title: Agent Versions of Connected Peers

panels.description: Number of currently open streams, by protocol and direction, as reported by the IPFS node.
panels.title: Number of Streams by Protocol and Direction

panels.description:
The number of peers, as reported by the IPFS node's peer store.
This counts by peer ID.
panels.title: Number of Peers

options.content:
### Process and Go Runtime Metrics

This lists metrics exported by IPFS and the Go runtime, as well as system metrics.

panels.description: CPU time used, calculated over 30 minutes
panels.title: CPU Seconds

panels.description: Open file descriptor count
panels.title: Open FDs

panels.description: Uptime of the IPFS node (not the system)
panels.title: Node Uptime

panels.description: IPFS version running and Go compiler version used to produce it.
panels.title: IPFS and Go Version
